title: Scripting support on text terminal (Feature Request)
author: mcarbonneaux
body_snippet: While be fun to add support for scripting on text terminal like [SPSL SuperPutty fonctionality](https://github.com/jimradford/superputty/wiki/SPSL-Reference-(SuperPuTTY-Scripting-Language)) but with [expect](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expect) support.

iterations.description: Scripting/expect support for terminal sessions is a major architectural feature far outside the current project scope and would require embedding a scripting engine, terminal session interception, and event hooks — effectively a different product

comments.author: kmscode
comments.snippet:
Reference #181 

We are looking to get away from PuTTY as a default mechanism with mRemoteNG since is causes a number of UI/UX headaches around window focus... 

But will leave this open as a generic "Scripting support on text terminal" request not specifically tied to SuperPuTTY Scripting Language.

comments.author: AeSix
comments.snippet:
Well, that's crap. The only reason I use mRemoteNG is for tabbed putty.  Now you're saying not only are you not going to incorporate Rutty scripting, but you're getting rid of PuTTY altogether?
Damned shame.

comments.author: sparerd
comments.snippet: We aren't planning on removing putty, it just won't be the default ssh provider. We still intend on supporting putty for the long term

comments.author: mbirth
comments.snippet: If possible, please don't create another abstract language but rather implement something like the Lua scripting engine (like [ExtraPutty](http://extraputty.com/features/lua.html) has) or maybe even Python.

comments.author: mcarbonneaux
comments.snippet:
Spsl are juste request/response language... Very similar to expect... Is why using expect while be more adapted to the need... And not reinventing the wheel.... 

Lua/python or other higth level scripting language are to higth for this type of use I think....

comments.author: mbirth
comments.snippet:
> Lua/python or other higth level scripting language are to higth for this type of use I think....

But they can be used for complex workflows, e.g. generating a 2FA token or fetching login data from a file/database. SPSL seems extremely limited in comparison.

If you add "expect" support, will it also support branching and loops (if/while)?

comments.author: mcarbonneaux
comments.snippet: They exist csharp library like https://github.com/wiwanek/Expect.NET for expect

comments.author: AeSix
comments.snippet:
I'd love to be able to use bash scripting to automate the client, as well as to have the client push data to the server, which can be executed on various triggers, such as on connection, pre-disconnection, and to watch for strings from the remote server.  This could potentially work on Windows as well as Linux (and maybe Mac?) 

More realistically, on a Windows client, PS could be used for the same tasks, with it being able to push bash snippets to the server as needed.  

Many server admins...

notes:
AI triage: Scripting/expect support for terminal sessions is a major architectural feature far outside the current project scope and would require embedding a scripting engine, terminal session interception, and event hooks — effectively a different product
Approach: Out of scope for current roadmap; would require fundamental architecture changes to intercept terminal I/O and embed a scripting runtime
